I first met Moskowitz on a crisp day in the spring of 2010 at the Harvard Club in Midtown Manhattan.
As a researcher, I was ahead of my time.”
I was struggling to survive and didn’t have the luxury of being a moral creature.
“I did the best science I could.
“There’s no moral issue for me,” he said.
As we talked, he made clear that while he has worked on numerous projects aimed at creating more healthful foods and insists the industry could be doing far more to curb obesity, he had no qualms about his own pioneering work on discovering what industry insiders now regularly refer to as “the bliss point” or any of the other systems that helped food companies create the greatest amount of crave.
shownText:
In making these sauces, Campbell supplied the ingredients, including the salt, sugar and, for some versions, fat, while Moskowitz supplied the optimization.
Many of the Prego sauces — whether cheesy, chunky or light — have one feature in common: The largest ingredient, after tomatoes, is sugar.
“As the sensory intensity (say, of sweetness) increases, consumers first say that they like the product more, but eventually, with a middle level of sweetness, consumers like the product the most (this is their optimum, or ‘bliss,’ point).”
A mere half-cup of Prego Traditional, for instance, has the equivalent of more than two teaspoons of sugar, as much as two-plus Oreo cookies.
“More is not necessarily better,” Moskowitz wrote in his own account of the Prego project.
It also delivers one-third of the sodium recommended for a majority of American adults for an entire day.
Well, yes and no.
One thing Gladwell didn’t mention is that the food industry already knew some things about making people happy — and it started with sugar.

I first met Moskowitz on a crisp day in the spring of 2010 at the Harvard Club in Midtown Manhattan.
As a researcher, I was ahead of my time.”
I was struggling to survive and didn’t have the luxury of being a moral creature.
“I did the best science I could.
“There’s no moral issue for me,” he said.
As we talked, he made clear that while he has worked on numerous projects aimed at creating more healthful foods and insists the industry could be doing far more to curb obesity, he had no qualms about his own pioneering work on discovering what industry insiders now regularly refer to as “the bliss point” or any of the other systems that helped food companies create the greatest amount of crave.

The military has long been in a peculiar bind when it comes to food: how to get soldiers to eat more rations when they are in the field.
“So I started asking soldiers how frequently they would like to eat this or that, trying to figure out which products they would find boring,” Moskowitz said.
On the other hand, mundane foods like white bread would never get them too excited, but they could eat lots and lots of it without feeling they’d had enough.”
The answers he got were inconsistent.
They know that over time, soldiers would gradually find their meals-ready-to-eat so boring that they would toss them away, half-eaten, and not get all the calories they needed.
“They liked flavorful foods like turkey tetrazzini, but only at first; they quickly grew tired of them.
But what was causing this M.R.E.-fatigue was a mystery.
Moskowitz’s path to mastering the bliss point began in earnest not at Harvard but a few months after graduation, 16 miles from Cambridge, in the town of Natick, where the U.S. Army hired him to work in its research labs.
title: The Extraordinary Science of Addictive Junk Food - NYTimes.com
